headline.main: PERSONALITIES AND AGGRESSIONS OF MR: BUTLER; SHEECH OF HON. HENRY WILSON, OF MASSACHUSETTS. In the Senate of the United States, June 13, 1856.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. BUTLER having concluded tile speech which he commenced yesterday, assailing the State of Massachusetts and Mr. SUMNER--Mr. WILSON obtained the floor, and spoke as follows: Mr. WILSON-Mr. President, I feel constrained, by a sense of duty to my State, by personal relations to my colleague and friend, to trespass for a few moments upon the time and attention of the Senate.
docs.abstract: Speech against Mr Butler in the Senate

headline.main: REPUBLICAN NATIONAL CONVENTION.; Grand Ratification Meeting at Philadelphia. A Yeung Men's National Convention to Held in Harrisburg. DOINGS AT TRENTON---SPEECH OF THE CANDIATE FOR VICE-PRESIDENT. Unanimity and Harmony Prevail. Report on the Conference with the North Americans. THIRD AND LAST DAY. Balloting for a Vice-President. INTERESTING SPEECHES FROM REPRESENTATIVES OF THE DIFFERENT STATES, FOR VICE-PRESIDENT, WM. L. DAYTON, OF NEW-JERSEY.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Convention met again this morning, and the ball was crowds to excess. Soon after 10 o'clock the Convention was called to order, and prayer was offered by Rev. Mr. LEVY, after which the President declared the first business in order in to be a cansideration of the following resolution:

headline.main: A Palatable Diet for a Man Hard-Up. ?? the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It is often a wonder to us ??

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday Messrs. BREVOORT, DUGANNE and SHEA, members of Assembly, of the Tenant House Special Committee, accompanied by Mr. DOWNING, Superintendent of Sanitary Inspection, and the Health Wardens of the First, Third and Fifth Wards, made a careful examination of the First, Third and Fifth Wards.

headline.main: NEW - YORK CITY.; The Horiticultural Show. Anniversary of the Baptist Historical Society. Board of Education. That Slave Brig. Common Council Commitiees. Plowing Under Clover

docs.lead_paragraph: The Havadji, in making his bow, once asked in the words of the poet HAFIZ, " Of what use is a flower?" and the sage replied, " A flower is good to smell." " And I am good to smell it," quoth the poet, and forthwith regaled himself. So long as today lasts, all men and women in New-York may be as the poet HAFIZ.

headline.main: PRESIDENTIAL.; Col. Benton Accepts the Nomination for Governor and Indorses Buchanan.

docs.lead_paragraph: TO THE CITIZENS OF MISSOURI. I have come to the determination, at this place, to accept the Democratic nomination for the office of Governor of Our State, induced to it by no paltry calenlation of the chances of an election, but wholly and entirely upon considerations of public good. The nomination of Mr. BUCHANAN for the Presidency determines my course in relation to the Governorship.
docs.abstract: Defends his conduct towards Chas Sumner
